answers: Te Deum [or “Te Deum laudamus”; accept “Thee, O God, we praise”]
parts: A performance of a piece of what name celebrating Louis XIV’s recovery from surgery saw a staff strike Jean-Baptiste Lully’s foot?
William Walton’s setting of the Te Deum was named for one of these events in 1952. Handel composed Zadok the Priest for one of these events.
This French baroque composer’s setting of the Te Deum is said to celebrate the 1692 Battle of Steinkirk. This composer wrote the opera The Pleasures of Versailles as composer for Louis XIV’s son.

answers: symmetry breaking [prompt on a partial answer; accept explicit symmetry breaking or spontaneous symmetry breaking]
Mermin-Wagner-Hohenberg-Berezinskii theorem [or Coleman theorem; prompt on partial answers]
bosons [accept Nambu-Goldstone bosons; or Higgs boson]
parts: Name this phenomenon in which small fluctuations acting on a system crossing a critical point prevent said system from becoming invariant under operations such as rotations and translations.

This theorem, under the assumptions of finite temperatures and short-range interactions, states that continuous symmetries cannot be broken in one and two dimensions. The two-dimensional Ising model shows that this theorem does not apply to discrete symmetries.
Proofs of the Mermin-Wagner theorem usually consider the special class of these particles named for Nambu and Goldstone. These particles include a famous one named for Higgs.

answers: matrilineal descent [accept any answer stating something like the mother is a Jew]
parts: Description acceptable. Text from the Mishnah resulted in the rabbinic law convention among Orthodox and Conservative Jews that only people who convert to Judaism or have Jewish ancestry of this kind are Jewish.

This body of Jewish law is laid out in the Shulchan Aruch. Hard-line Orthodox sects regard complete observance of this law code as necessary for converts to become Jews, which includes their undergoing circumcision and immersion in a mikveh.
According to the halakha, even an observance of these 613 Jewish commandments does not make someone a Jew. These commandments, found in the Torah, are attributed to Rabbi Simlai.

Name this effect in which subtle environmental stimuli cause changes to a person’s response to other stimuli. Chapter 4 of Daniel Kahneman’s Thinking Fast and Slow summarizes many studies of this effect, several of which were found to be non-replicable, and Kahneman has since called the study of this effect a “trainwreck.”

Kahneman has shown skepticism towards priming studies because of their sample size. In a 1971 paper, he and this Israeli developer of prospect theory criticized the use of small sample sizes in social psychology research.

Kahneman further conceded that researchers can try to get published by “hacking” the p-value of these kinds of tests. These tests are named after a statement whose null variety can be rejected or not rejected.

answers: geishas [prompt on courtesans; prompt on prostitutes] <Ed. JM>
parts: Identify this practice where Japanese women and later men would soak scraps of iron in a mixture of sake or vinegar and apply it to themselves to make themselves more beautiful.

During the Edo Period, women started buying luxury combs, some of which would be made from this material. Guangzhou craftsmen specialized in making concentric spheres from this material, although state factories making goods from this material in China were closed in 2017.
Women in this profession still apply an "honorable white" paste to their faces. These “art people” train to play the samisen and are skilled in flower arranging and entertaining men.

This 1837 novel, its author’s first, relates the adventures of a naive gentlemen who travels around observing life. Installments sold just okay until the introduction of amusing Cockney servant Sam Weller, after which it became incredibly popular. However, its author saw none of the money because he had signed away the copyright.

This author of The Pickwick Papers went into the publishing business himself with the magazine Household Words. When sales started to go down, he revived them by using the magazine to publish his shortest novel, Hard Times.

This novel was Dickens’ most profitable in his own lifetime. Characters in this novel include Bradley Headstone, a respectable schoolteacher by day who tries to drown his romantic rival Eugene Wrayburn over the affections of Lizzie.

answers: phages [or American Phage Group; accept bacteriophage]
parts: Name this German biophysicist who names that experiment, along with Salvador Luria.

Delbruck, Luria, and Alfred Hershey were leaders of a group named after these viruses that infect and replicate within bacteria. The Luria-Delbruck Experiment featured E. coli cultures, whose agar contained the T1 examples of these.

The precursors to the Hershey-Chase experiments done by Griffith, and Avery, Oswald, and McCarty used this species of bacteria to study the role of DNA. Griffith used the virulent III-S and non-virulent II-R strains of this species.

answers: the Beast is played by the same actor as the antagonist [or reasonable equivalents]
Oedipus Rex [or Oedipus the King] <Ed. DS>
parts: Name this French author who directed the 1946 film version of Beauty and the Beast and wrote about the destructive one-upmanship between siblings Elisabeth and Paul in his novel Les Enfants Terribles.

Cocteau added Freudian themes to his Beauty and the Beast story by making this unusual choice, which only becomes obvious to the audience in the final scenes of the film after the Beast dies and is resurrected as a normal human.

Cocteau wrote the libretto for Stravinsky’s opera adaptation of this play, which had previously been analyzed by Freud. Cocteau’s own adaptation of this play, The Infernal Machine, begins with the appearance of the ghost of the protagonist’s father Laius.

answers: Black, Brown and Beige: A Tone Parallel to the History of the Negro in America [or B, B & B]
parts: Identify this long, three movement tone poem. The first of these movements is further subdivided into “Work Song,” “Come Sunday,” and “Light.”
Black, Brown and Beige is a long piece by this jazz pianist from Washington, D.C., whose band recorded standards such as “It Don’t Mean a Thing (If It Ain’t Got That Swing)”.

This song, a collaboration between Ellington and Barney Bigard, was reworked from a Lorenzo Tio creation. Its singer’s title emotion “goes stealin' down to my shoes” ever since “my baby said goodbye.”

answers: charity single [or charity song; or charity album; or charity record]
parts: The 1985 track "Stars" was what type of song?

This song kicked off the charity single craze and raised money for famine relief in Ethiopia.  Thusly, a common refrain in this song is “feed the world”, and this song ends with “Let them know it’s [the title time].”

Another Christmas-themed charity song is “I Feel It in My Bones” by this Las Vegas band, whose 2007 song “Don’t Shoot Me Santa” also had its proceeds sent to AIDS charities. This band released songs like “Run for Cover” in 2017.
This lagoon, which adjoins a port that Sapurmanat Niyazov renamed after himself, seasonally fluctuates between being a lake and a bay.
When it isn’t a lake of its own, Karabogaz Kol is a bay of this sea, the largest inland body of water in the world.
The Aral Sea is shrinking due to its draining by two Soviet canals built to irrigate this crop, Uzbekistan’s main export.
Identify this Scottish finance minister, who resigned and went into exile in Venice following the 1718 collapse of a major bubble.
The aforementioned bubble was named for this territory, which shares its name with a modern-day US state. The Sieur de la Salle explored the delta of a river of this name in the late 17th century.

The Mississippi Bubble burst following the demands of a prince from this house to sell twenty-five million shares in the company. A “great” general from this family fought with the Spanish at the Battle of the Dunes, tried to get himself elected King of Poland, and led the army of Louis XIV at the 1674 Battle of Seneffe.
Name this mathematician, who proved that any sufficiently large graph has an epsilon-regular partition, a result known as his regularity lemma.

Szemerédi used his regularity lemma to prove a celebrated theorem stating that any set of integers with positive upper density contains arbitrarily large examples of these things. which are sequence with a constant difference between pairs of elements.

This other Hungarian mathematician has a namesake conjecture on arithmetic progressions generalizing Szemerédi’s theorem. This extremely prolific mathematician names a number measuring the collaboration distance between him and any other person.
Name this Ken Liu story, in which the narrator’s mother makes origami animals that come to life, including a tiger nicknamed Laohu. This story also titles the 2016 collection in which it appears.

Ken Liu also translated this Liu Cixin [tsih-SHEEN] novel, the first in the Remembrance of Earth’s Past trilogy, into English. In this novel, the Trisolarans invade Earth because they cannot predict the Stable and Chaotic Eras of their own planet.

In 2012, “The Paper Menagerie” became the first work of fiction to win all three major science fiction awards: the World Fantasy Award, the Nebula Award, and this award, also given to The Three-Body Problem.

Name this ancient Greek term for weakness of will, which is contrasted with a word that means “in power.” An example of this trait is when someone chooses something when they know something else is the best.

This philosopher’s 1970 paper “How is Weakness of the Will Possible?” answered the title question by asserting that irrationality is real. He formulated the Swampman thought experiment in “Knowing One’s Own Mind.”

Aristotle’s characterization of the impulse to do bad that overcomes reason during akrasia resembles this philosopher’s view that evil actions were only possible due to ignorance. In Plato’s Protagoras, this philosopher argues against a sophist.
Name these devices, whose momentum transfer varieties include ones named diffusion and turbomolecular. These devices remove gas molecules from a fixed volume to decrease pressure to nearly zero torr.

Cryopumps, or cryogenic pumps, are vacuum pumps that feature low temperature surfaces that can be covered by zeolites or this substance. This molecular sieve can be made from decomposing sources like peat, wood, and coal at high temperatures and features pores that help raise the surface area for reactions.
The large surface area of activated charcoal makes it ideal for adsorption, which is modeled by this man’s isotherm, which assumes adsorbates are an ideal gas.

answers: Russian crown serfs [or Russian state serfs; or state peasants; or crown peasants; prompt on serfs; prompt on peasants]
parts: Identify these Russian subjects, distinct from those of the appanages and those of the land. Despite the frequent transfers of these people to the nobility, they constituted over 40% of Russia’s population by the 1850s.
This Russian emperor freed the serfs and was assassinated by members of the People’s Will in 1881.

After being forced to cultivate this crop, serfs in Viatka Province protested that its “seed are antichrist,” because they thought it derived from the apple that tempted Eve. They’re not plums, but the War of the Bavarian Succession is sometimes named for this food.

answers: marine paintings [or seascapes; or ship paintings; or naval paintings]
parts: Carmichael was best known for painting these types of scenes, and even published a book on how to make them. Thomas Birch was the first prominent American painter of these scenes, and Princeton's Art Museum displays a Fitz Henry Lane painting in this genre set at Gloucester and shrouded in fog.

Another Carmichael book explored the art of marine painting in this medium. Thomas Girtin inaugurated the English tradition of landscapes in this medium, in which pigments are applied to the paper surface via a brush soaked with the namesake liquid.

Carmichael's painting HMS Erebus and Terror in the Antarctic is similar in theme to The Sea of Ice by this other painter. This Romantic artist's other marine-themed paintings include the allegorical The Stages of Life, in which the five differently-aged people in the foreground are contrasted with the ships in the distance.

answers: Tim O’Brien [or William Timothy O’Brien] <Ed. JO>
parts: Name this war, also the setting of Phil Klay’s collection Redeployment. In a Ben Fountain novel, Billy Lynn is hailed as a hero and invited to the Cowboys’ Thanksgiving game when his actions in this war are caught on camera.

Dakotah Lister loses an arm while serving in Iraq in this author’s short story “Tits-Up in a Ditch.” In another story, she wrote about the homosexual relationship between Ennis del Mar and Jack Twist, who work at a Wyoming ranch.
Another work of contemporary war fiction is The Things They Carried, a collection of Vietnam War stories by this author.

answers: Pedro Menéndez de Avilés [prompt on de Avilés]
parts: Name this Spanish Captain-General, who was tasked by Philip II with preventing French settlement in the Florida area. He established the colony of La Florida after fighting off the French settler Jean Ribault.
In 1565, Menéndez founded this oldest still occupied city on the continental United States.
Santa Elena, the temporary capital of La Florida, is near Port Royal and the Marine Corps Recruit Depot of Parris Island in this modern-day state.
